More Notes: The paper mentions that the SCCO2 doubles the earlier PAGE09 values due to model updates.
Refers to Kalkuhl and Wenz (2020) tripling the SCCO2 based on earlier results ($37–$132).
Refers to the effect of long-term persistence increasing the outcome even more ($220–$417).
This result reflects updates from PAGE09 to PAGE-ICE, including climate sensitivity and AR5 updates.
Final SCCO2 value reflects damage persistence introduced to GDP.
Increase in SCCO2 is attributed almost entirely to increased social costs in the Global South.
No notable change is shown due to regional empirical damage estimates.
Persistence reflects impacts on growth trajectory, especially in Africa, South Asia, and Latin America.
Mean global GDP is 30% lower with empirical persistence distribution, relative to the SSP2-4.5 growth path without persistence.
Mean growth loss due to persistence exceeds the GDP growth rate in the whole Global South, causing economic contraction.
Share of Monte Carlo simulations for which a region reaches the lower bound for GDP per capita.
Share of Monte Carlo simulations for which a region reaches the lower bound for GDP per capita.
Share of Monte Carlo simulations for which a region reaches the lower bound for GDP per capita.
SCCO2 increases fifteenfold if 10% of economic damages persist via reduced growth.
The mean SCC exceeds the estimate without damage persistence by an order of magnitude, suggesting high sensitivity to equity weighting parameters and methodologies.
SCCO2 exceeds $5000 if current persistence is only 20% and decreases by an annual 0.5%
Needs a minimum of 3% per year reduction in persistence to see this SCCO2
Mean increase due to annual temperature variability
Mean increase due to annual temperature variability
The page presents a box plot graph showing percentage of GDP in 2100 due to different damages. Specific numeric values are not provided in the page text.
The page includes SCCO2 distributions with and without interannual temperature variability, but specific numeric values are not detailed in the text.
All model specifications without growth effects produce lower values of the mean SCCO2 (indicated by a negative value).
Differences between PAGE09 and PAGE-ICE show that the previous SCCO2 results have also decidedly underestimated damages in the Global South (indicated by a positive value).

For all the PAGE-ICE-based model specifications, we find higher mean values for SSP2-4.5 than for SSP5-8.5 (indicated by a positive value). This is because radiative forcing is logarithmic in concentration
For SSP1-2.6, climate change-induced damages are much lower compared to SSP2-4.5, leading to significantly lower SCCO2 values if no damage persistence is considered (indicated by a negative value).
